Hi I am trying to make a differential swerve drive as a fun project during the summer, but I do not understand the math behind it. (I understand yg probably have a library for this stuff but pretend im making this almost from scratch)

Can you describe what part of the math you are struggling with?

What resources have you used so far? What parts do you understand, and where do you start to feel confused?

It’s a swerve drive, but you replace each module with a differential drive.

Remember that a “tank drive” is just a differential drive, so you can really think of it as a swerve drive whose module setpoints cascade to multiple tank drives. You can even implement this with the WPILib DifferentialDrive class if you want - the kinematics are exactly the same.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2024-07-01T15:24:49.559Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":137,"readers_count":136,"score":117.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":468203,"topic_slug":"help-me-learn-differential-swerve-drive-programming","display_username":"Eli Barnett","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12381,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!"},"post_url":"/t/help-me-learn-differential-swerve-drive-programming/468203/3","custom_user_title":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3404263,"name":"Tyler Veness","username":"calcmogul","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/calcmogul/{size}/128045_2.png","created_at":"2024-07-01T16:04:07.146Z","cooked":"

You basically just use normal swerve inverse kinematics, then apply differential dynamics to the velocity commands.

# Diffy swerve module controllers

Swerve inverse kinematics gives module velocity and heading commands v_cmd and
heading_cmd. The following are the voltage commands for the motors.

u_v = PID(v, v_cmd)
u_heading = PID(heading, heading_cmd)

## Normal swerve

A normal swerve module has a velocity motor (output u_1) and a turn motor
(output u_2).

u_1 = u_v
u_2 = u_heading

## Diffy swerve

A differential swerve module has two motors where running them the same
direction gives linear velocity and the opposite direction gives rotation.

u_1 = u_v + u_heading
u_2 = u_v - u_heading

Getting your feedback control accurate enough is the hard part.
